None of this is to minimize the climate importance of permafrost, glaciers, or the Amazon. These systems indisputably have significant potential to intensify climate change and sea level rise.

But sometimes understanding these systems better can provide a bit of hope. (16)

But wouldn't carbon released from permafrost + Amazon degradation accelerate climate change, adding heat to the kettle even if you turn the burner down?

It would, but even high-end estimates of carbon release from permafrost are still dwarfed by current human emissions. (10)

Permafrost in barren lowlands where water can collect in summer and focus the sun's rays will thaw sooner.

Permafrost on a cool, forested, north-facing slope might be fairly resilient to climate change.

Nor does the whole region/kettle increase in temperature evenly. (5)
